book.title: Genghis Khan and the Making of the Modern World
book.author: Jack Weatherford
book.description: A revisionist perspective on Genghis Khan and the Mongol Empire, challenging traditional Western views and highlighting the progressive aspects of Mongol rule and their lasting impact on world civilization.

events.name: Birth of Temüjin (Genghis Khan)
events.description: Temüjin was born with a blood clot in his hand, considered an omen of great leadership. He would become Genghis Khan.
events.significance: Beginning of the life of the man who would unite the Mongol tribes and create the largest contiguous land empire in history.

sources.title: Genghis Khan - Wikipedia
sources.notes: From Weatherford's book - Chapter 1: The Blood Clot

events.name: Abduction of Börte
events.description: Börte, Temüjin's wife, was abducted by the Merkits. Temüjin formed powerful alliances to rescue her, demonstrating his emerging leadership.
events.significance: First demonstration of Temüjin's ability to forge alliances and his determination. This event shaped his path to power.

sources.title: Weatherford book - Part I: The Reign of Terror on the Steppe

events.name: Temüjin Proclaimed Genghis Khan
events.description: At a great kurultai (assembly), Temüjin was proclaimed 'Genghis Khan' (Universal Ruler), uniting the Mongol tribes under a single leader for the first time.
events.significance: Founding of the Mongol Empire. Weatherford emphasizes this marked the beginning of unprecedented cultural exchange and expanded trade.

sources.title: Genghis Khan - Wikipedia
sources.notes: Weatherford: This marks the beginning of conquests that subjugated more lands in 25 years than Rome in 400

events.name: Raid on Western Xia
events.description: Genghis Khan led a large-scale raid into the Western Xia, who agreed to Mongol terms the following year.
events.significance: First major external conquest, establishing Mongol military reputation beyond the steppe.

events.name: Invasion of Jin Dynasty Begins
events.description: Genghis Khan declared war on the Jin Dynasty, beginning a 23-year conflict. The Mongol armies invaded from the north in three groups.
events.significance: Weatherford describes this as demonstrating Mongol siege warfare capabilities and beginning the conquest of one of the world's most populous regions.

sources.title: Mongol conquest of the Jin dynasty - Wikipedia
sources.notes: Part II: The Mongol World War (1211-1261)

events.name: Battle of Yehuling
events.description: First major battle between the Mongol Empire and Jin dynasty at a mountain pass. Decisive Mongol victory.
events.significance: Key victory opening the path to Beijing and demonstrating superior Mongol cavalry tactics.

sources.title: Mongol conquest of Jin dynasty - Wikipedia

events.name: Siege and Capture of Beijing (Zhongdu)
events.description: After years of campaigning, the Mongols besieged and captured the Jin capital of Zhongdu (modern Beijing), sacking the city.
events.significance: Capture of one of Asia's greatest cities. Weatherford notes this brought northern China under Mongol control.

events.name: Annexation of Qara Khitai
events.description: General Jebe annexed the Central Asian state of Qara Khitai, expanding Mongol territory westward.
events.significance: Extended Mongol influence into Central Asia, setting stage for conflict with Khwarazm.

events.name: Otrar Massacre
events.description: The governor of Otrar seized a Mongol trade caravan and executed the merchants. Genghis Khan sent envoys demanding justice; they were murdered.
events.significance: Weatherford emphasizes this as the casus belli for the devastating Mongol conquest of the Khwarazmian Empire. The Khan's commitment to protecting trade routes is highlighted.

sources.title: Weatherford - Chapter 4: Spitting on the Golden Khan

events.name: Invasion of Khwarazmian Empire
events.description: Genghis Khan invaded the Khwarazmian Empire in retaliation for the Otrar massacre, beginning one of history's most devastating campaigns.
events.significance: Weatherford describes this as toppling a vast Central Asian empire and opening the path to the Middle East and Europe.

events.name: Siege of Bukhara
events.description: The Mongols besieged and captured Bukhara, one of the greatest cities of Central Asia. Much of the city was destroyed.
events.significance: Weatherford describes the destruction of this major cultural and commercial center. Key event in the Khwarazm conquest highlighted in the book.

events.name: Conquest of Samarkand
events.description: After Bukhara, the Mongols conquered Samarkand, another jewel of the Silk Road and major center of Islamic culture.
events.significance: Further expansion of Mongol control over Central Asian trade routes. Weatherford notes the irony that Mongol destruction ultimately revitalized these trade networks.

events.name: Devastation of Transoxiana and Khorasan
events.description: The Mongol armies systematically devastated the regions of Transoxiana and Khorasan, destroying cities and agricultural infrastructure.
events.significance: Weatherford documents the massive demographic and economic impact, while also noting how this destruction paradoxically led to later cultural integration.

sources.title: Weatherford - Part II: The Mongol World War

events.name: Battle of the Kalka River
events.description: Mongol reconnaissance forces under Subutai and Jebe defeated a much larger coalition of Rus' princes in their first encounter with European armies.
events.significance: Weatherford emphasizes this demonstrated Mongol military superiority and provided intelligence for future European campaigns.

sources.title: Battle of the Kalka River - Wikipedia

events.name: Death of Genghis Khan
events.description: Genghis Khan died during a campaign against the Tangut kingdom. In early 1227, a horse threw him, causing internal injuries from which he never recovered.
events.significance: Weatherford notes that despite his death, the empire continued to expand under his successors, eventually covering 24 million km². His legal code and administrative systems persisted.

sources.title: Genghis Khan - Death - Wikipedia
sources.notes: Weatherford discusses his hidden burial and lasting legacy

events.name: Ögedei Khan Elected Great Khan
events.description: At a kurultai, Ogedei, Genghis Khan's third son, was formally elected as the new Great Khan, succeeding his father.
events.significance: Weatherford notes Ogedei departed from tradition by building a permanent capital city (Karakorum), marking a shift toward more settled governance.

events.name: Completion of Jin Dynasty Conquest
events.description: The Jin dynasty finally collapsed after the siege of Caizhou, completing the conquest begun by Genghis Khan in 1211.
events.significance: Elimination of major rival power in northern China, consolidating Mongol control.

sources.title: Mongol conquest of Jin dynasty - Wikipedia

events.name: Mongol Invasion of Russia Begins
events.description: Under Batu Khan and General Subutai, the Mongols launched a massive invasion of the Russian principalities.
events.significance: Weatherford describes this as beginning the Mongol domination of Eastern Europe. Chapter 6: The Discovery and Conquest of Europe.

events.name: Sack of Kiev
events.description: Mongol forces under Batu Khan stormed and sacked Kiev, the 'mother of Rus' cities'. The city was devastated and would not recover its former prominence.
events.significance: Destruction of Kiev marked the end of Kievan Rus' as a unified power.

events.name: Battle of Legnica
events.description: Mongol forces defeated a coalition of Polish and German knights. Duke Henry II was killed and beheaded. The Mongols used superior tactics to devastate European heavy cavalry.
events.significance: Weatherford emphasizes this battle, occurring the same day as Mohi, showed coordinated Mongol operations across vast distances and European military inferiority.

sources.title: Battle of Legnica - Wikipedia
sources.notes: Weatherford - Chapter 6: The Discovery and Conquest of Europe

events.name: Battle of Mohi
events.description: Batu Khan and Subutai inflicted a devastating defeat on King Béla IV's Hungarian army. Weatherford notes this killed half of Hungary's population.
events.significance: Considered one of the most devastating defeats in European history. It left Central Europe defenseless and demonstrated Mongol military supremacy at its peak.

events.name: Death of Ögedei Khan
events.description: The Great Khan Ögedei died, causing all Mongol princes to return to Mongolia for the succession kurultai. This ended the westward expansion into Europe.
events.significance: Weatherford argues this death likely saved Western Europe from Mongol invasion. The succession crisis halted what could have been a complete conquest of Europe.

sources.title: Ögedei Khan - Wikipedia
sources.notes: Weatherford discusses the significance in Part II conclusion

events.name: Möngke Khan Elected Great Khan
events.description: After a period of instability, Möngke, grandson of Genghis Khan, was elected Great Khan.
events.significance: Möngke's rule saw renewed military campaigns and consolidation of Mongol power.

events.name: Hulagu's Middle Eastern Campaign
events.description: Hulagu Khan led a massive Mongol army into the Middle East with orders to subdue all Muslims who refused submission.
events.significance: This campaign would devastate the Islamic world's political and cultural centers, ending the Abbasid Caliphate.

sources.title: Mongol conquest of the Abbasid Caliphate - Wikipedia

events.name: Siege and Destruction of Baghdad
events.description: Hulagu Khan's forces besieged and captured Baghdad, executing the last Abbasid Caliph and massacring much of the population. Libraries and scholarly works were destroyed.
events.significance: Weatherford notes the fall of Baghdad ended the Abbasid Caliphate (750-1258) and is seen as marking the end of the Islamic Golden Age. The city's population dropped from 1 million to 100,000.

events.name: Kublai Khan Proclaimed Great Khan
events.description: Kublai Khan was proclaimed Great Khan, though his younger brother Ariq Böke contested the succession, leading to civil war.
events.significance: Weatherford describes Kublai's reign as marking a shift toward Chinese administration and the beginning of the empire's fragmentation. Chapter 8: Khubilai Khan and the New Mongol Empire.

events.name: End of Toluid Civil War
events.description: Kublai Khan defeated his brother Ariq Böke, consolidating his position as Great Khan.
events.significance: Kublai established control, but Weatherford notes the empire was now effectively divided into separate khanates.

events.name: Establishment of Yuan Dynasty
events.description: Kublai Khan officially issued an imperial edict giving the empire the Han-style dynastic name 'Great Yuan', establishing the Yuan Dynasty.
events.significance: Weatherford emphasizes this showed Mongols adopting Chinese imperial framework. First non-Han dynasty to rule all China.

sources.title: Yuan Dynasty - Wikipedia
sources.notes: Chapter 8: Khubilai Khan and the New Mongol Empire

events.name: Conquest of Song Dynasty Complete
events.description: The Yuan conquest of the Song Dynasty was completed. Kublai became the first non-Han emperor to rule all of China proper.
events.significance: Weatherford notes this unified all of China under Mongol rule for the first time, completing the conquest begun in 1211.

events.name: Bubonic Plague Begins in China
events.description: The plague started in China. Weatherford notes China lost half its population in the next twenty years.
events.significance: Beginning of pandemic that would devastate Eurasia. Weatherford argues the Mongol-created trade networks enabled the plague's spread, contributing to the empire's collapse.

sources.title: Weatherford - Part III: The Global Awakening (1262-1962)

events.name: Collapse of Ilkhanate (Persia)
events.description: The Ilkhanate (Mongol-ruled Persia) collapsed due to rebellion and fragmentation.
events.significance: Weatherford describes this as the loss of Mongol control over western territories, beginning the empire's fragmentation.

events.name: Plague Reaches Europe
events.description: The plague spread along Mongol trade routes, reaching Europe by 1347. Weatherford notes Europe would lose a third of its population.
events.significance: The interconnected world created by the Mongols enabled the pandemic's spread. Weatherford argues this paradoxically shows both the power and vulnerability of the global system they created.

sources.title: Black Death - Wikipedia
sources.notes: Weatherford - Part III: Plague travels along Mongol-created networks

events.name: Fall of Yuan Dynasty
events.description: Ming rebels took over China, ending Mongol rule. Weatherford notes the Ming built walls to keep others out and themselves in.
events.significance: End of Mongol Empire as a unified entity. Weatherford argues the Mongol legacy persisted in trade networks, legal systems, and cultural exchange they established. Part III concludes with empire's collapse and lasting influence.

sources.title: Yuan Dynasty - Wikipedia
sources.notes: Weatherford - Final collapse marking end of Mongol rule
